facts.text: Delhi High Court confirmed the conviction of the appellant under Sections 353/332/333 of the Indian Penal Code with sentence of one year rigorous imprisonment on each count, fine of Rs. 400, and in default four months further rigorous imprisonment under Section 333 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Delhi had confirmed the conviction ,,of the appellant under Section 353/332/333 of the Indian Penal , Code, and a sentence of one years regorous imprisonment on each ,count, and also to be fine of Rs. 400/-, and, in default of payment

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal is Criminal Appeal No. 199 of 1970 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 199 of 910. Appeal by Special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th

facts.text: Delhi High Court judgment dated 12th November 1969 in Criminal Appeal No. 103 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th November, 1969 of the Delhi High Court at New Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 103 of 1968.

facts.text: On 17-3-1967 at 4:30 p.m. in Rameshwar Nagar, appellant obstructed Rattan Singh, Maharaj Singh, Raghbir Singh (Section Inspectors) and Dunger (Peon) of Delhi Municipal Corporation while they attempted to seize his buffalo for milk tax.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the appellant had, on 17-3-1967, at 4,30 p.m., in Rameshwar Nagar, obstructed Sarvshri Rattan Singh, Maharaj Singh and Raghbir Singh, Section Inspectors, and Dunger, a Peon of the Delhi Municipal Corporation, when they went to seize a buffalo belonging to the appellant in the discharge of their duty to, realise the milk tax from him,

facts.text: Appellant struck Rattan Singh on the nose causing it to bleed and fracture.

anchor.surface_text: and struck Rattan Singh on the numbere with the result that it bled and was also fractured.

facts.text: Attempt to realize Rs. 153.75 as arrears of milk tax plus Rs. 10 recovery charges.

anchor.surface_text: The Main contention on behalf of the appellant is that the attempt to realize Rs. 153.75 as arrears of milk tax together with Rs. 10/ as recovery charges was illegal,

facts.text: Commissioner issued order dated 22-7-1959 under Section 491 delegating powers to Inspectors of the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: An order of the Commissioner dated 22-7-1959 under Section 491 of the Act, delegating the Commissioners powers to Inspectors of the Corporation, set that question, at rest.

facts.text: No contention that Inspectors did not act under colour of their office.

anchor.surface_text: We find that it has not been contended anywhere that the Inspectors ,did not act under the colour of their office.

facts.text: Appellant did not plead that officers were not known to him as Inspectors or could not show authority.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did not plead, in defence, that the officers concerned were not known to him as Inspector-, of the Corporation authorised to collect tax or that they could not show any authority for performing their duties.

facts.text: On facts found, appellant objected to taking of buffalo and then gave blow to Rattan Singh's nose which bled and fractured.

anchor.surface_text: On facts found, it has to be assumed that the appellant had objected to the taking of his buffalo, and, as this was of no avail, he had given a blow to Rattan Singh on the nose which bled and was also fractured as a result.

facts.text: No notice of demand under Section 154 served in the instant case.

anchor.surface_text: We, however, do not think that, in view of the provisions of Section 99 I.P.C. it is enough to hold that there had been no notice of demand in the instant case.

facts.text: Appellant told officers he did not have ready money to pay instantly and did not refuse to pay.

anchor.surface_text: All that the appellant told them was that he did not have ready money to pay up instantly. He did not refuse to pay.

facts.text: Inspectors acted honestly in exercise of powers delegated by Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: They were acting honestly in the exercise of the powers delegated to them by the Commissioner.

facts.text: Supreme Court maintains convictions but reduces sentences to period already undergone and sets aside fine.

anchor.surface_text: But, in as much as they had acted in an improper manner in demanding immediate payment and tried to seize the animal prematurely under ,a misconception about the mode of exercise of their powers under .Section 161 of the Act, the sentences imposed upon the appellant are excessive. We think that the ends of justice will be served by maintaining the .,convictions but reducing the sentences to the period already undergone by the appellant. Consequently, we set aside the fine imposed upon the appellant and reduce the sentences passed upon him to the period already undergone.

facts.text: High Court held Section 161 empowers seizure anytime after tax due without notice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had accepted the submission on behalf of the Prosecution that Section 161 of the Act empowered the Inspectors of the Corporation to seize and remove the appellants buffalo for nonpayment of the tax as it gave an over-riding power to resort to this method of enforcing payment a. any time after the tax has become du.-.

facts.text: Appellant contended no compliance with Section 154 notice of demand.

anchor.surface_text: because compliance with the provisions of the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957  hereinafter referred to as the Act , for the payment and recovery of taxes, and, in particular with the requirements for a notice of demand contained in Section 154 of the Act, was wanting so that he had a right to private defence.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by BEG, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BEG, J.-

issues.text: Whether Section 161 of the DMC Act permits seizure of animal for unpaid tax at any time after tax due without prior notice of demand and deeming as defaulter under Sections 154 and 155

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had accepted the submission on behalf of the Prosecution that Section 161 of the Act empowered the Inspectors of the Corporation to seize and remove the appellants buffalo for nonpayment of the tax as it gave an over-riding power to resort to this method of enforcing payment a. any time after the tax has become du.-.

issues.text: Whether there is no right of private defence against a public servant acting in good faith under colour of office even if the act is not strictly justifiable by law under Section 99 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Section 99 of the I.P.C. which lays town There is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done, by a. public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office, though that act may not be strictly justifiable by law.

issues.text: Whether the Inspectors' action without prior notice under Section 154 amounted to lack of good faith so as to deny protection under Section 99 IPC

anchor.surface_text: In view of the provisions of Section 99 I.P.C. it is enough to hold that there had been no notice of demand in the instant case. The action of the Inspectors did not become vitiated by bad faith simply for that reason.

issues.text: Whether Section 161 should be interpreted to require prior notice under Section 154 to deem a person a defaulter before seizure, using harmonious construction and reading down to avoid constitutional issues

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that, out of two possible interpretations, the one which confines the content of such power of seizure to reasonable limits and fair modes of operation should be preferred lest the validity of the provision itself becomes questionable. The provisions of the Act, set out above, are capable, we think, of being reasonably so interpreted as to confine the ambit of power contained in Section 161

arguments.claim: Attempt to realize Rs. 153.75 as arrears of milk tax together with Rs. 10 as recovery charges was illegal due to non-compliance with Section 154 notice of demand, entitling appellant to right of private defence

anchor.surface_text: The Main contention on behalf of the appellant is that the attempt to realize Rs. 153.75 as arrears of milk tax together with Rs. 10/ as recovery charges was illegal, because compliance with the provisions of the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957  hereinafter referred to as the Act , for the payment and recovery of taxes, and, in particular with the requirements for a notice of demand contained in Section 154 of the Act, was wanting so that he had a right to private defence.

arguments.claim: Unless Section 154 notice served and 30 days elapsed without payment or appeal, person not defaulter under Section 155, so Section 161 inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the learned Counsel for the appellant, based upon the provisions of Section 154 and Section 155 of the Act, is that, unless Section 154 is complied with, so that a notice of demand is served upon a person from whom tax has become due, be cannot file an appeal. It was emphasized that he will be deemed to be in default only if the demand is not satisfied within 30 days and no appeal is filed against it.

arguments.claim: Section 491 does not require naming every inspector; general delegation to class sufficient

anchor.surface_text: An order of the Commissioner dated 22-7-1959 under Section 491 of the Act, delegating the Commissioners powers to Inspectors of the Corporation, set that question, at rest. We do not think it could be argued that Section 491 requires the Commissioner of the Commissioners powers upon every Inspector by name. It is enough if there is a general order, as there is in this case, indicating the class of officers to whom the Commissioner had delegated his .powers under any section.

arguments.claim: Inspectors acted under colour of office; appellant did not plead lack of knowledge or authority

anchor.surface_text: We find that it has not been contended anywhere that the Inspectors ,did not act under the colour of their office. The appellant did not plead, in defence, that the officers concerned were not known to him as Inspector-, of the Corporation authorised to collect tax or that they could not show any authority for performing their duties.

arguments.claim: Lack of notice does not vitiate good faith under Section 99 IPC; Inspectors acted honestly

anchor.surface_text: We, however, do not think that, in view of the provisions of Section 99 I.P.C. it is enough to hold that there had been no notice of demand in the instant case. The action of the Inspectors did not become vitiated by bad faith simply for that reason. They were acting honestly in the exercise of the powers delegated to them by the Commissioner.

holdings.text: An order of the Commissioner dated 22-7-1959 under Section 491 of the Act, delegating the Commissioners powers to Inspectors of the Corporation, set that question, at rest. We do not think it could be argued that Section 491 requires the conferment of the Commissioners powers upon every Inspector by name. It is enough if there is a general order, as there is in this case, indicating the class of officers to whom the Commissioner had delegated his powers under any section.

anchor.surface_text: An order of the Commissioner dated 22-7-1959 under Section 491 of the Act, delegating the Commissioners powers to Inspectors of the Corporation, set that question, at rest. We do number think it companyld be argued that Section 491 requires the company- ferment of the Commissioners powers upon every Inspector by name. It is enough if there is a general order, as there is in this case, indicating the class of officers to whom the Commissioner had delegated his .powers under any section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General delegation to class of officers sufficient; no need to name each; supported by precedent Kanwar Singh vs. Delhi Administration.

holdings.text: There is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done, by a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office, though that act may not be strictly justifiable by law.

anchor.surface_text: We find that it has number been companytended anywhere that the Inspectors ,did number act under the companyour of their office. The appellant did number plead, in defence, that the officers companycerned were number known to him as Inspector-, of the Corporation authorised to companylect tax or that they companyld number show any authority for performing their duties. Hence,  1  1965  1  SCR p. 711 he prosecution has relied upon Section 99 of the I.P.C. which lays town There is numberright of private defence against an act which does number reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done, by a. public servant acting in good faith under companyour of his office, though that act may number be strictly justifiable by law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution reliance on Section 99 IPC; appellant did not dispute colour of office or lack of authority.

holdings.text: In view of the provisions of Section 99 I.P.C. it is enough to hold that there had been no notice of demand in the instant case. The action of the Inspectors did not become vitiated by bad faith simply for that reason. They were acting honestly in the exercise of the powers delegated to them by the Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: We, however, do number think that, in view of the provisions of Section 99 I.P.C. it is enough to hold that there had been numbernotice of demand in the instant case. The action of the Inspectors did number become vitiated by bad faith simply for that reason. They were acting honestly in the exercise of the powers delegated to them by the Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural error in notice does not imply bad faith; Inspectors acted honestly under delegated powers; no refusal to pay by appellant.

holdings.text: Out of two possible interpretations, the one which confines the content of such power of seizure to reasonable limits and fair modes of operation should be preferred lest the validity of the provision itself becomes questionable. The provisions of the Act, set out above, are capable, we think, of being reasonably so interpreted as to confine the ambit of power contained in Section 161 of the Act to situations in which the person from whom the tax is to be realized can be deemed to be a defaulter under Sections 154 and 155.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that, out of two possible interpretations, the one which companyfines the companytent of such power of seizure to reasonable limits and fair modes of operation should be preferred lest the validity of the provision itself becomes questionable. The provisions of the Act, set out above, are capable, we think, of being reasonably so interpreted as to companyfine the ambit of power companytained in Section 161

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction with Sections 152-155, 156-159 requiring notice; reading down drastic seizure power to defaulters only to avoid arbitrariness and constitutional issues.

holdings.text: Section 99 did confer a protection upon the employees of the Corporation who acted in good faith under the colour of their office.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we think that Section 99 did companyfer a protection upon the employees of the Corporation who acted in good faith under the companyour of their office.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied to facts: Inspectors' action not vitiated; appellant only said no ready money, did not refuse; no plea of bad faith.

holdings.text: The ends of justice will be served by maintaining the convictions but reducing the sentences to the period already undergone by the appellant. Consequently, we set aside the fine imposed upon the appellant and reduce the sentences passed upon him to the period already undergone.

We think that the ends of justice will be served by maintaining the .,convictions but reducing the sentences to the period already undergone by the appellant. anchor.surface_text: An order of the Commissioner dated 22-7-1959 under Section 491 of the Act, delegating the Commissioners powers to Inspectors of the Corporation, set that question, at rest. We do number think it companyld be argued that Section 491 requires the company- ferment of the Commissioners powers upon every Inspector by name. It is enough if there is a general order, as there is in this case, indicating the class of officers to whom the Commissioner had delegated his .powers under any section.
